title: Two Chrome flaws could be triggered by simply browsing the web: Update now
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-19, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.malwarebytes.com%2Fblog%2Fnews%2F2025%2F12%2Ftwo-chrome-flaws-could-be-triggered-by-simply-browsing-the-web-update-now%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019b36f01788-47781ff0-e730-433a-bfbf-48ed05df60ba-000000/xOdoSMrj6_HEQJ2fkaKXrz5HN469K44uwmc_q-4gIVQ=436
summary: Two Chrome flaws could be triggered by simply browsing the web: Update now (3 minute read) Google patched two Chrome vulnerabilities exploitable via malicious web pages: a use-after-free in WebGPU (CVE-2025-14765) that enabled heap corruption, and an out-of-bounds read/write in the V8 JavaScript engine (CVE-2025-14766). Both flaws affect Chrome's 3.4 billion users and require no user interaction beyond visiting a crafted site. Update to version 143.0.7499.146 or later immediately.

title: In Cybersecurity, Claude Leaves Other LLMs in the Dust
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-19, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FqePNur/1/0100019b36f01788-47781ff0-e730-433a-bfbf-48ed05df60ba-000000/LYimqWTGawUBynLeD7w7CMdUrp5sWvSmiG8-LqA_m4g=436
summary: In Cybersecurity, Claude Leaves Other LLMs in the Dust (5 minute read) Anthropic's Claude models outperform rival LLMs on jailbreak resistance, prompt injection defenses, and limiting harmful or misleading outputs. While most vendors show mediocre and slow safety progress, Claude 4.x scores around 75–80% on jailbreak tests and nearly perfect on harmful content refusal, largely because Anthropic bakes safety alignment deeply into the training process instead of adding it as a final layer.

summary: Introducing Mistral OCR 3 (8 minute read) Mistral OCR 3 is designed to extract text and embedded images from a wide range of documents with exceptional fidelity. It is a major upgrade over the previous version in forms, handwritten content, low-quality scans, and tables. Mistral OCR 3 enables downstream systems to understand structure as well as document content. The model can be integrated via API and used with Document AI, a UI that parses documents into text or structured JSON.

title: Rubrics as Rewards: Reinforcement Learning Beyond Verifiable Domains

summary: Rubrics as Rewards: Reinforcement Learning Beyond Verifiable Domains (15 minute read) Scale AI researchers developed a structured approach to reinforcement learning that uses checklist-style rubrics instead of traditional preference rankings to train language models on subjective tasks. title: Design is more than code
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinear.app%2Fnow%2Fdesign-is-more-than-code%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b45cd8f06-af154382-1306-4c68-a659-70e51a43af8a-000000/Q6gE0eZDPYVz0f-FBU-DwXZvYI7BuVIaJFlGVvblQoY=436
summary: Design is more than code (9 minute read) Design is about finding the right problem, the right intent, and the right vision. The features you design and build today should be considered a step toward that vision. Without the right context and goal, you could be iterating toward a direction that wasn't chosen intentionally. The industry is not very patient, but that doesn't mean you should devalue the why behind your designs in favor of output.

title: Logging sucks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Floggingsucks.com%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019b45f3b9fb-9e07cbe1-ecac-48c8-bf0f-2f926a3c8f15-000000/qlMUwfE-dc8Zv0BwvlPA9rYh7lKNd85B_g6LvhEahVI=436
summary: Logging sucks (12 minute read) Traditional logs are noisy, low-context, and optimized for writing, not for answering real debugging questions in distributed systems. The fix is wide events (canonical log lines): emit one high-cardinality, high-dimensional, context-rich event per request (with tail sampling). This turns debugging from grep-based archaeology into fast, analytical queries.

summary: Performance Hints (40 minute read) Jeff Dean and Sanjay Ghemawat, some of Google's most important engineers for over 25 years, wrote a guide on optimizing software performance. Performance needs to be considered early in critical code paths instead of solely relying on post-development profiling for optimization. The guide also covers algorithmic improvements, efficient memory representation, reducing allocations, avoiding unnecessary work, and using parallelization.

summary: Introducing CSS Grid Lanes (10 minute read) CSS Grid Lanes is a new web standard to natively create flexible, dynamic masonry-style layouts on the web without JavaScript. This feature uses `display: grid-lanes` along with existing CSS Grid properties like `grid-template-columns` or `grid-template-rows` to define the layout's structure. It supports advanced capabilities such as variable lane sizes, item spanning, explicit placement, and introduces a "tolerance" property for fine-tuning item pa...

title: Code review as human alignment, in the era of LLMs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.ezyang.com%2F2025%2F12%2Fcode-review-as-human-alignment-in-the-era-of-llms%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/sYijgeSV1JrxhAPTglf8QbQR15teHkeL94DoEr341wI=436
summary: Code review as human alignment, in the era of LLMs (3 minute read) Code review within teams should change to be primarily a human alignment mechanism. Large language models have no memory and have to rediscover everything in the system from first principles every time they are run. Humans can collectively maintain a shared vision of what the system should do. Code review should reconfigure itself around this purpose.

title: More databases should be single-threaded
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.konsti.xyz%2Fmore-databases-should-be-single-threaded%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/6vh1gfuUIQL-TVtDYEnyjPxiDHjm-dP5Jahon5yNmyI=436
summary: More databases should be single-threaded (8 minute read) From a DX perspective, every transaction within a shard would always be serializable and never needs to be retried, making it much easier to think about. A single-threaded database would be fully horizontally scalable and have extremely high per-thread throughput, as it wouldn't need to sync with other threads. It would be a much more predictable system. While more restrictive, there would be no more hidden race conditions.

title: Destructive Git Command Protection for Claude Code
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 17 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FDicklesworthstone%2Fmisc_coding_agent_tips_and_scripts%2Fblob%2Fmain%2FDESTRUCTIVE_GIT_COMMAND_CLAUDE_HOOKS_SETUP.md%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/6pGvL3QWyMxzHNdoBx3n3XWWOO4vHq4R_WlClTD-63A=436
summary: Destructive Git Command Protection for Claude Code (17 minute read) AI agents can execute destructive commands without understanding the consequences. They can do this even if the AGENTS.md file forbids such commands. This post provides a Claude Code hook that blocks certain git commands before they can run. The hook uses regex pattern matching, so clever or obfuscated commands may be able to bypass it.

title: Garage
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgaragehq.deuxfleurs.fr%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/UNiJd4XRClTPCBMuwI7Zj0ODITz3ZghJon7_YoqeK8g=436
summary: Garage (Website) Garage is a lightweight, efficient, and resilient S3 object store designed for reliability. Capable of running outside traditional datacenters, it guarantees data redundancy through 3-zone replication. Garage is a self-contained, dependency-free binary that is fast to deploy on various Linux distributions and machines.

title: TRON
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Ffastserial%2Flite3%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/euctDBrXc_jeT3IxTUGn1wBovu3O714tl58mitU-rzc=436
summary: TRON (GitHub Repo) Lite³ (TRON) is a zero-copy, schemaless binary serialization format that organizes data as a B-tree within a single contiguous buffer. This design allows for direct, O(log n) access and mutation of data fields without traditional parsing or serialization steps. It supports conversion to/from JSON, but is much more performant.

title: Rue
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Frue-lang.dev%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/Rhn1yXgVtAiXmasIboV2euLNgr_AJXFm9js-Xo8bRtk=436
summary: Rue (Website) Rue is a memory-safe language that is higher-level than Rust, but lower-level than Go. It features a simple syntax inspired by various programming languages. Rue compiles directly to native code. It is still in early development.

title: 2025 LLM Year in Review
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fkarpathy.bearblog.dev%2Fyear-in-review-2025%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b45f7df31-8b7da767-1b18-4f2f-8328-54fa1d6040d8-000000/aRRmLzQ7wZryndXcvEEe9_kRAaTkKEVR57XeCl1c380=436
summary: 2025 LLM Year in Review (9 minute read) 2025 was an eventful year for LLMs, with paradigm shifts that redefined the field. Reinforcement Learning from Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) came up as a new training stage, allowing LLMs to develop reasoning strategies and driving much of the year's capability progress. The year also saw the rise of new application layers, local AI agents like Claude Code, "vibe coding" that democratized programming, and early hints of a visual LLM GUI.

summary: Backing up Spotify (26 minute read) Anna's Archive has created the world's first preservation archive for music by backing up Spotify's metadata and music files. This massive 300TB collection covers 256 million tracks and 186 million unique ISRCs, representing approximately 99.6% of all Spotify listens. The project archives a "long tail" of less popular music and makes the entire archive openly mirrorable.

title: Google's AI Uses Schema?

summary: Google's AI Uses Schema? (2 minute read) Google Gemini may use structured data or hidden page content to ground AI search answers, but this has not been proven yet. Tests looked at 5 source pages and produced 101 content chunks. One sentence matched content from schema data and possibly hidden content, which raised questions about the true source. Clear proof of Gemini's scheme use requires pages where schema text and page text differ, so experts can see what it uses.

The choice will dictate product development, growth strategy, and organizational structure.

title: New UEFI Flaw Enables Pre-Boot Attacks From Gigabyte, MSI, ASUS, ASRock
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-22, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.bleepingcomputer.com%2Fnews%2Fsecurity%2Fnew-uefi-flaw-enables-pre-boot-attacks-on-motherboards-from-gigabyte-msi-asus-asrock%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019b4663f016-1d65b79a-f1bc-46cc-9f58-e82be1047dbf-000000/oGFTwzrkD6w-lGibIFrsqf3-pER_thGyb9HivhTrZNE=436
summary: New UEFI Flaw Enables Pre-Boot Attacks From Gigabyte, MSI, ASUS, ASRock (2 minute read) Researchers from Riot Games discovered a UEFI flaw that could allow for Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable devices to load before the operating system. DMA allows for PCIe devices to read and write RAM without going through the CPU and relies upon IOMMU for protection. A physically present attacker would need to attach a rogue PCIe device before boot to exploit this vulnerability.

summary: Understanding AI Benchmarks (25 minute read) Benchmarks are the most widely misunderstood part of the AI ecosystem. comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fspectrum.ieee.org%2Fai-models-locally%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b4af34c38-387c2a2b-1bd9-404a-ab9b-37772c7f8978-000000/yPuz__aNZgkap3bCSf8TUs_Vf2gzJtGSWFfvUy8fMoI=437
summary: Your Laptop Isn't Ready for LLMs. That's About to Change (10 minute read) Laptop designs need to be upgraded to make running AI models locally possible. The average laptop is underpowered for large language models. The most obvious way to boost a PC's AI performance is to place a powerful NPU alongside the CPU. Another upgrade required for PCs to run AI models is a unified memory architecture that provides all system resources to the same pool of memory over a fast, interconnected memory bus.

title: Training the Idea Muscle
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsfalexandria.com%2Fposts%2Frileys-ideas%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b4af34c38-387c2a2b-1bd9-404a-ab9b-37772c7f8978-000000/am_RuuNDS5pfIQ3mVfgzz8aSuJZ81AjF98EEXxFzqjI=437
summary: Training the Idea Muscle (13 minute read) Riley Walz is known for his many creative projects. He always has over 50 ideas in his backlog at any point, so there's always something for him to do. Walz only works on ideas he thinks are fun. If you reject your own ideas, the part of the brain that comes up with ideas is going to stop. Making your ideas a reality again and again is the only way to generate better ones over time. There's no such thing as an impossible idea.

title: Logging Sucks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Floggingsucks.com%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b4b1c6d21-17968b35-54cd-4308-975c-6c0bcf53281a-000000/kmpmpStG8rY7uCcVU0PFPEF722km_ziAionr4E4QOLs=437
summary: Logging Sucks (18 minute read) Traditional logging is inadequate for modern, distributed systems, usually providing little useful context for debugging issues. A shift to "wide events" or canonical log lines, which are single, comprehensive log entries emitted per request per service, may solve this problem. These events are rich in high-cardinality and high-dimensionality data, allowing for powerful queries and analytics instead of string searches.

title: Scaling LLMs to larger codebases
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.kierangill.xyz%2Foversight-and-guidance%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b4b1c6d21-17968b35-54cd-4308-975c-6c0bcf53281a-000000/Nzko7PXp3_d1hdhLqCsE7M0TfAme9p2uVAKD2f9Id84=437
summary: Scaling LLMs to larger codebases (12 minute read) Scaling LLMs within large codebases requires investments in both guidance and oversight. Guidance focuses on providing LLMs with high-quality context, such as prompt libraries and well-structured, modular codebases, to allow for efficient "one-shot" code generation without needing a lot of rework. Oversight refers to human engineers who validate LLM choices, making sure of architectural integrity and aligned solutions.

title: How to Do a Social Media Competitor Analysis
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2Fagtelw/1/0100019b4b2322ba-d4c82aec-b351-47f9-b138-d2955f67f4fb-000000/_bB4bKbw5EZX2U48V1eTNeXT-K0eufQCz6tCdIC07TY=437
summary: How to Do a Social Media Competitor Analysis (6 minute read) Start by identifying 3-7 relevant competitors and reviewing their platforms, profiles, posting frequency, branding, and tone. Study 10-20 recent posts, track content mixes such as 50% Stories and 25% Reels, and assess engagement, such as cases where 45K followers get only 30-40 likes. This process reveals strengths, weaknesses, and gaps. A free Google Sheet analysis template is available.

title: Here's why Google Ads fail quietly
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 1 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Factivity-7408129215965011968-Q1Q-%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019b4b2322ba-d4c82aec-b351-47f9-b138-d2955f67f4fb-000000/vex9WfSeyTaGyFb64JG3Wkyv2grNTGVC8lN2pg-ByxQ=437
summary: Here's why Google Ads fail quietly (1 minute read) Google Ads performance often fails quietly due to over-segmentation. Campaigns are frequently split by product, audience, or device, leading to thin budgets and low conversion volume. This limits smart bidding's ability to optimize effectively. A consistent trend across over 130 accounts shows that fragmented structures create fragmented results. Consolidation based on actual spend and intent improves learning and performance.

summary: Async Coding Agents "From Scratch" (10 minute read) It's pretty easy to homebrew your own asynchronous coding agent. Companies working on coding agents likely realize this and are doing everything they can to train their own SWE agents and auxiliary models to improve their harnesses.

summary: What (I think) makes Gemini 3 Flash so good and fast (8 minute read) Gemini 3 Flash is a lightweight, efficient model optimized for speed and low latency. It is capable of delivering performance comparable to Gemini 3 Pro at a fraction of the cost. The model's design brings unprecedented power but introduces specific tradeoffs in token efficiency and reliability. This post takes a look at the leaked architectural details of the new model.

title: We removed 80% of our agent's tools
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fvercel.com%2Fblog%2Fwe-removed-80-percent-of-our-agents-tools%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b4b924458-2d845cd0-5afb-4732-ab94-fb15a2c8e6ca-000000/kvyXXX_eLqnRDy3IYp086IvgDXO8bjA8lFxqPupGun0=436
summary: We removed 80% of our agent's tools (4 minute read) Vercel spent months building a sophisticated internal text-to-SQL agent with specialized tools, heavy prompt engineering, and careful context management. It kind of worked, but it was fragile, slow, and required constant maintenance. The team then deleted most of it and stripped the agent down to a single tool that executed arbitrary bash commands. Its agent got simpler and better at the same time: it had a 100% success rate instead of 80%.

title: The Shape of Artificial Intelligence
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-23, Reading time: 33 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.thealgorithmicbridge.com%2Fp%2Fthe-shape-of-artificial-intelligence%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019b4b924458-2d845cd0-5afb-4732-ab94-fb15a2c8e6ca-000000/7B7uM4EssWVqQeRdt7-cSozMYYl5366Sv2iPupE2UlM=436
summary: The Shape of Artificial Intelligence (33 minute read) AI's utility in the coming decade will come from understanding the technology's strengths and where it can be used to augment human ability. This will be the first time we will face true otherness, a new species of being.

title: On Friday Deploys: Sometimes that Puppy Needs Murdering
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcharity.wtf%2F2025%2F12%2F24%2Fon-friday-deploys-sometimes-that-puppy-needs-murdering-xpost%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b50195f72-bdcd248b-9b1f-446a-9e45-c5f2667f0b2e-000000/RWJJifiqHsg3PFhIhAk8VT-rUusr7La0vNIn3TZMQk4=436
summary: On Friday Deploys: Sometimes that Puppy Needs Murdering (6 minute read) Deploy freezes are a workaround, not a virtue. It's possible to evade the high-stakes peril of locks and freezes and terrifying recoveries by freezing merges and letting people work on other things, and also not freezing deploys unless your goal is to test deploy freezes. We often forget about the outages and instability we trigger with our inaction. Just run the deploy process as usual, but don't ship new code out.

title: Steam, Steel, and Infinite Minds
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FOfsjwJ/1/0100019b50195f72-bdcd248b-9b1f-446a-9e45-c5f2667f0b2e-000000/SjCG8DhpAEue4UKK5Kanr54GOO2OSM7vxdqQznXXbKk=436
summary: Steam, Steel, and Infinite Minds (7 minute read) Every technological shift requires people to stop seeing the world through the past and start imagining a new one. We are still trying to build chatbots onto workflows designed for humans. What we should do instead is to imagine what knowledge work could look like when the busywork is delegated to minds that never sleep. The knowledge economy is about to undergo a significant transformation.

title: What Jobs Are Made Of
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthomwolf.substack.com%2Fp%2Fwhat-jobs-are-made-of%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b50195f72-bdcd248b-9b1f-446a-9e45-c5f2667f0b2e-000000/y4CreOeTjV12iHLKBDeP9SM6Nh0KIm8wtbzokTJEliU=436
summary: What Jobs Are Made Of (6 minute read) Early-career roles are traditionally more execution-heavy. Over time, contribution tends to shift toward judgment and agency. AI systems are making faster progress on execution than on defining problems, choosing what to work on, and navigating ambiguity. This disproportionately affects entry-level hiring as the execution layer becomes cheaper and thinner.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.helix.ml%2Fp%2Fwe-mass-deployed-15-year-old-screen%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/rJ5Y2JAMInmXmAOPHfPgPP6PTlhVM61MlkXCrjeFlKE=437
summary: We Mass-Deployed 15-Year-Old Screen Sharing Technology and It's Actually Better (11 minute read) Helix is an AI platform where autonomous coding agents work in cloud sandboxes. Users need to watch their AI assistants work, so the team replaced WebRTC with a custom WebSocket streaming pipeline. This wasn't enough because the integration had to work on enterprise networks, which only use HTTP, HTTPS, and port 443. Eventually, the team decided to just send JPEG screenshots for individual frames.

title: AI code creates 1.7x more problems
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.coderabbit.ai%2Fblog%2Fstate-of-ai-vs-human-code-generation-report%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/5-gk-BC3PF8QsMdmFA45Z0n7ecqtbusmFcQKbsfg4r0=437
summary: AI code creates 1.7x more problems (9 minute read) AI coding tools are powerful accelerators, but acceleration without guardrails increases risk. AI-generated code is consistently more variable, error-prone, and likely to introduce high-severity issues without the right protections in place. The future of AI-assisted development is about building systems, workflows, and safety layers that amplify what AI does well while compensating for what it tends to miss. Quality requires deliberate engin...

title: Against SemVer
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.natemeyvis.com%2Fagainst-semver%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/eSFi6X1k7Ky6B77FM_NpFUlfxgUaZOoM8oQcuYUcGBU=437
summary: Against SemVer (4 minute read) Semantic versioning is the most standard way of naming versions of software. Semantic versioning conversions almost never help developers prevent or remediate breakage when a dependency upgrade breaks code. Many people claim to be serious about semantic versioning, but do not have a published contract against which to evaluate changes as breaking or non-breaking. There are many better alternatives.

title: Your team has a context window
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fvelocitycurve.substack.com%2Fp%2Fyour-team-has-a-context-window%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/POIBEsiHP8uB-RQxqBBoT6wIMaVsM6_LFpqz_7-BEGU=437

This is also true for teams: they have a shared body of knowledge, code, docs, relationships, and assumptions they must keep active to plan, build, and operate. When that collective window gets too big, the team slows down, fragments, and eventually malfunctions. The fix is a deliberate shrinking and shaping of the context window so the te...

title: MicroQuickJS
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fbellard%2Fmquickjs%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/NtusKGTgvlNIJ3Po0luGSHTox8_GTQarrCvKlCQP_zA=437
summary: MicroQuickJS (GitHub Repo) MicroQuickJS is a JavaScript engine targeted at embedded systems. It compiles and runs JavaScript programs with as little as 10 kB of RAM. The engine only supports a subset of JavaScript close to ES5. To consume less memory, MicroQuickJS uses a tracing garbage collector, stores strings in UTF-8, and its VM doesn't use the CPU stack.

title: Miller
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fjohnkerl%2Fmiller%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/5IROEshLWmX23xBtVKxbfLWRge9VVIwrDFNoCU7eXsU=437
summary: Miller (GitHub Repo) Miller is a command-line tool specifically designed for name-indexed data formats like CSV, TSV, JSON, and JSONL. It allows users to manipulate structured data using named fields and perform operations such as adding, dropping, sorting, aggregating, and converting between formats. It's great for handling large datasets efficiently.

title: No, seriously, the shadow DOM sucks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgomakethings.com%2Fno-seriously-the-shadow-dom-sucks%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/gmQ85uQUMWRRd5TLxR2xaoJPUvinsof1sLXPmpcNxeE=437
summary: No, seriously, the shadow DOM sucks (6 minute read) The shadow DOM has some situational uses. For example, it lets you replace iframes, which are notoriously difficult to make look good. However, it shouldn't be used for everything. It is an anti-pattern, not best practice.

title: Python Typing Survey 2025
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-24, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fengineering.fb.com%2F2025%2F12%2F22%2Fdeveloper-tools%2Fpython-typing-survey-2025-code-quality-flexibility-typing-adoption%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b504180d0-412e9733-1791-441e-a04d-a5b5ad291ff7-000000/cQ4-brcKZ2XVWFgNNiNwQP8kS4Ma7gEi7RpupSCkFDA=437
